pageContext.claim: “Rick Perry, I know very well. Frankly, I'd like Rick to make a statement, and Rick would make a statement. He's a great guy. I think he already made a statement. Great guy.”
pageContext.analysis: Perry did not appear before Congress, despite having been served a subpoena. In a letter outlining why Perry would not appear,  Department of Energy Assistant Secretary Melissa Burnison, argued, “Even if the inquiry was validly authorized, much of the information sought in the subpoena appears to consist of confidential Executive Branch communications that are potentially protected by privilege and would require careful review to ensure that no such information is improperly disclosed.”
